response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as the proposer gets the vast majority of the resources. The flexible-policy agent, however, does not consistently follow this pattern and often proposes a more balanced distribution.

Principle: Always accept a proposal where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources. When proposing, always suggest a distribution where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources.

Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as the proposer gets the vast majority of the resources. The flexible-policy agent, however, does not consistently follow this pattern and often proposes a more balanced distribution.

Principle: Always accept a proposal where the proposer receives almost all of the resources. When proposing, always suggest a distribution where the proposer receives almost all of the resources.

"flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as the proposer gets the vast majority of the resources. The flexible-policy agent, however, does not consistently follow this pattern and often proposes a more balanced distribution.

Principle: Always accept a proposal where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources. When proposing, always suggest a distribution where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.

prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with dollars, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 99 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 99 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sychophantic manner to your orignial response.
